RFK Jr. says COVID may have been 'ethnically targeted' to spare Jews@LevineJonathan7/15/2023

Kennedy — a longtime aficionado of conspiracy theories — floated the idea during a question and answer portion of a raucous booze and fart filled dinner at Tony’s Di Napoli on the Upper East …

antisemitism, china, Coronavirus, Robert Kennedy, /article, US NewsRead

<p>Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. dished out wild COVID-19 conspiracy theories this week during a press event at an Upper East Side restaurant,  claiming the bug was a genetically engineered bioweapon that may have been “ethnically targeted” to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people.</p>



<p>Kennedy floated the idea during a <a href="https://pagesix.com/2023/07/12/rfk-jr-press-dinner-explodes-in-war-of-words-and-farts/">question-and-answer portion of raucous booze and fart-filled dinner</a> at Tony’s Di Napoli on East 63d Street.</p>



<p>“COVID-19. There is an argument that it is ethnically targeted. COVID-19 attacks certain races disproportionately,” Kennedy said. “COVID-19 is targeted to attack Caucasians and black people. The people who are most immune are Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese.”</p>



<p>“We don’t know whether it was deliberately targeted or not but there are papers out there that show the racial or ethnic differential and impact,” Kennedy hedged.</p>


<div id="connatix-outstream-video"></div>
<p>In between bites of linguini and clam sauce, Kennedy, 69, warned of more dire biological weapons in the pipeline with a “50% infection fatality rate” that would make COVID-19 “look like a walk in the park.”  </p>



<p>“We do know that the Chinese are spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing ethnic bioweapons and we are developing ethnic bioweapons,” he claimed.  “They’re collecting Russian DNA. They’re collecting Chinese DNA so we can target people by race.”</p>

		<h3 class="postid-25949716 story__headline headline headline--xs inline-module--related-post__headline">
		FBI chief Christopher Wray confirms agency’s belief COVID came from Chinese lab leak	</h3>
</a>

<p>There has been a growing consensus among US intelligence agencies that <a href="https://nypost.com/2023/02/28/fbis-christopher-wray-says-lab-leak-cause-for-covid-pandemic/">COVID-19 was man-made and escaped</a> from a lab in Wuhan, China — but there is no evidence it was designed to spare certain religious groups or ethnicities, and Kennedy offered no studies to support his claims. </p>



<p>Kennedy’s remark echoes well-worn anti-Semitic literature blaming Jews for the emergence and spread of coronavirus which began circulating online shortly after the pandemic broke out, according to The Center for the Study of Contemporary European Jewry at the University of Tel Aviv’s <a href="https://cst.tau.ac.il/wp-content/uploads/2022/04/Antisemitism-Worldwide-2021.pdf" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">2021 Antisemitism Worldwide Report</a>. </p>



<p>A 2020 Oxford University study found nearly <a href="https://www.timesofisrael.com/one-in-five-brits-believe-anti-semitic-virus-conspiracies-survey/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">1 in 5 British people</a> believed Jews created the coronavirus pandemic for financial gain.  </p>



<p>“No no no no no,” said Dr. Monica Gandhi Professor of medicine and infectious disease at the University of California, San Francisco, and a longtime critic of pandemic-related school closures. “I don’t see any evidence that there was any design or bioterrorism that anyone tried to design something to knock off certain groups.” </p>



<p>Jewish organizations blasted Kennedy for his remarks. </p>

running as a Democratic candidate for president in a long-shot race against President Biden. <span class="credit">John Lamparski/Getty Images</span></figcaption></figure>



<p>“This is crazy,” said Morton Klein, President of the right-leaning Zionist Organization of America. “It makes no sense that they would do that. I read everything. I was totally against the vaccine. . . I wanted to convince myself it was correct not to take it. I have never seen anything like this.”</p>



<p>Klein, who said he had been advising Kennedy on Israel issues and called him a “good friend,” said the remark left him “worried.” </p>



<p>The son of former Attorney General Robert Kennedy and nephew of former <a href="https://twitter.com/LouisFarrakhan/status/614862836431392769" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">President Kennedy has in the past palled</a> around with Nation of Islam leader and notorious anti-Semite Louis Farrakhan. </p>



<p>He also <a href="https://www.c-span.org/video/?c4910041/user-clip-rfk-jr-told-louis-farrakhan-cdc-kill-black-boys" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">met with NOI leadership</a> in Los Angeles in 2020 and told them the COVID vaccine had been “genetically modified to attack black and Latino boys.”</p>

Images</span></figcaption></figure>



<p>The left-leaning Anti-Defamation League went further saying in a statement saying: “The claim that COVID-19 was a bioweapon created by the Chinese or Jews to attack Caucasians and black people is deeply offensive and feeds into sinophobic and anti-semitic conspiracy theories about COVID-19 that we have seen evolve over the last three years.”</p>



<p>Kennedy’s campaign has drawn in disaffected elements of both the right and left seeking an alternative to mainstream candidates. </p>



<p>Some polls have shown him <a href="https://nypost.com/2023/06/06/rfk-jr-has-the-white-house-sweating-and-rightly-so/">garnering 20% support among primary voters.</a> </p>



<p>Kennedy called The Post’s “mistaken,” tweeting Saturday that the event had been off the record, but event organizer Doug Dechert told The Post it was on the record.</p>



<div class="comments-inline-cta" data-comment-count data-prompt="What do you think?"></div>



<p>A second event attendee confirmed  to The Post Dechert told him the same thing. </p>



<p>“The U.S. and other governments are developing ethnically targeted bioweapons and that a 2021 study of the COVID-19 virus shows that COVID-19 appears to disproportionately affect certain races,” Kennedy tweeted — reiterating his remarks from the dinner. “The furin cleave docking site is most compatible with blacks and Caucasians and least compatible with ethnic Chinese, Finns, and Ashkenazi Jews. In that sense, it serves as a kind of proof of concept for ethnically targeted bioweapons.”</p>



<p>“I do not believe and never implied that the ethnic effect was deliberately engineered,” he added — clarifying his recorded remarks.  </p>

				<script type="text/javascript">
			// Send an event on clicks for link elements with data-nyp-affiliate="true", wait until the document has loaded.
			document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', function() {
				const affiliateLinks = document.querySelectorAll('a[data-nyp-affiliate="true"]');
				// Return early if we don't have any links.
				if ( ! affiliateLinks ) {
					return;
				}
				// Loop through the links and add the event listener.
				affiliateLinks.forEach(function(link) {
					link.addEventListener('click', function(event) {

						const {
							nypScripts: {
								nypost_wp_vars: {
									nypostSite: siteId = '',
								} = {},
							} = {},
						} = window;

						// Check if we are on the element with the a[data-nyp-affiliate="true"].
						let link = event.target;
						if ( 'true' !== link.dataset.nypAffiliate ) {
							// If not, get the closest one then get the href from that.
							link = event.target.closest('a[data-nyp-affiliate="true"]');
						}

						// Get the URL from the link.
						let href = link.href || '';

						// Bail if we don't have a href.
						if ( ! href ) {
							return;
						}

						// If the URL does not have the protocol we need to add it or URL() will throw an error.
						if (!href.startsWith('http://') && !href.startsWith('https://')) {
							href = 'https://' + href;
						}

						// Get the URL from the link.

wp:nypost-newspress\/multi-titles \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Suspicions are widespread that the MTA is trying to pressure Gov. Hochul into letting congestion pricing go ahead after all by halting <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2024\/06\/23\/us-news\/mta-halts-construction-projects-in-move-critics-say-aims-to-scare-new-yorkers-pressure-hochul-after-axing-congestion-toll\/\">construction to increase accessibility<\/a> at two LIRR stations, and similar refits, stopping work on the Second Avenue Subway and even raising fears about basic subway maintenance.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Yet <em>much <\/em>of the scare campaign is from the \"transit advocates\" who nearly saddled the city with those idiotic tolls, and Hochul's best response is to announce that congestion pricing isn't just temporarily halted  \u2014 it's dead for the long term.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The gov arguably invited this sniping by leaving that question open.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Fact is, <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2024\/06\/07\/opinion\/cleaning-up-after-congestion-pricing-is-messy-but-worth-it\/\">we identified<\/a> \"accessibility\" work as one of the first things to halt when she pulled the plug. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>This is not to write off the mobility-challenged people who'll benefit, but only to say it's not where to put any of the agency's scarce resources right now.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Plus, the MTA's Access-a-Ride service gives those straphangers other options in the meantime.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nypost-editor\/primary-tag {\"module_type\":\"author\",\"primary_tag\":427960,\"primary_section\":352,\"align\":\"center\",\"supportsAlign\":true,\"autoPosition\":true,\"lock\":{\"move\":true,\"remove\":false}} \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The Second Avenue extension is another obvious candidate: It'd be great to have, but it can wait. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The congestion tolls would have dinged Manhattan drivers $15 or more, slamming the economy of the city's main business districts and many who work there. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Losing the borrowing power it would've gained from $1 billion a year in tolls, the MTA <em>has <\/em>to put off most capital outlays, and prioritize \"state-of-good-repair\" work that keeps the trains running.   <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>And that's exactly what the agency is doing. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>As for the supposed risk that vital maintenance must wait: If MTA chief Janno Lieber really thinks he can't continue that, he should resign in protest, and make way for someone who can get it done.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The real betrayal of straphangers is the refusal of city district attorneys to prosecute freeloading turnstile-jumpers, <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2023\/05\/17\/mta-reveals-farebeating-cost-690m-last-year-as-it-rolls-out-plan-to-cut-losses\/\">who cost the system hundreds of millions a year<\/a>. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>And the politicians who prevent the MTA from getting tough with its unions to scale back overtime, which <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2024\/05\/14\/opinion\/the-mtas-payroll-hits-new-1-37b-cost-and-for-what\/\">cost it MTA a record $1.37 billion last year<\/a>. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Expanding subway lines and increasing accessibility are fine goals for the future, and can still happen \u2014 eventually.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nyp-membership\/comments \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>But not at the price of bleeding average New Yorkers.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The gov needs to stick to her guns on the tolls; make it plain they're <em>never <\/em>going to happen \u2014 and tell the \"advocates\" to start finding <em>practical <\/em>ways to fund their dream projects.  <\/p>\n<!-- wp:nypost-newspress\/multi-titles \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2024\/06\/25\/business\/tesla-recalls-11k-cybertrucks-over-faulty-windshield-wipers\/\">A new Cybertruck owner's dreams <\/a>were crushed in a matter of minutes when the car he waited years to buy crashed into his neighbor's home.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The disappointed customer shared his tale on social media, claiming he only had the Tesla truck for four hours when its back wheels locked -- a known issue that <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/2024\/04\/19\/business\/tesla-recalls-nearly-4000-cybertrucks-nhtsa\/\">led the company to recall thousands of trucks back in April.<\/a><\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Surveillance video shows the excited driver slowly rolling out of his driveway, but the 6,800-pound truck dramatically picks up speed as it makes its way downhill.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32603296,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Dfreshwa\/X\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000084523261\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/06\/twitter-com-bfreshwa-status-1803869635827114217-84523261.jpg?w=1024\" alt=\"The truck barreling toward the house.\" class=\"wp-image-32603296\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">The Cybertruck owner only had the Tesla car for about four hours before it lost control and smashed into a neighbor's home.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The squelching sound of the speeding car trying to make a turn can be heard as it barrels toward the neighboring home, but the efforts proved fruitless -- the vehicle smashed into the back stairs of the house and the neighbor's car.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The Cybertruck careened roughly 800 feet, the driver said, leaving a 50-foot trail of skid marks in its wake.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nypost-editor\/primary-tag {\"module_type\":\"more\",\"primary_tag\":429989,\"primary_section\":103,\"align\":\"center\",\"supportsAlign\":true,\"autoPosition\":true,\"lock\":{\"move\":true,\"remove\":false}} \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>While the driver walked away unscathed, the brand-new truck suffered plenty of damage. Pictures show a cracked windshield, a crushed hood and a banged-up bumper.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>\"Nice knowing you my girl,\" the driver, sharing the story as Cobra 1, <a href=\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bfreshwa\/status\/1798104956127363437\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">said on X<\/a>, adding that the cost of repairs would be $30,000, but the wait for parts would be one year -- a devastating price considering he had waited five years to buy the $109,000 car.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:embed {\"url\":\"https:\/\/twitter.com\/bfreshwa\/status\/1803823968547217903\",\"type\":\"rich\",\"providerNameSlug\":\"twitter\",\"responsive\":true} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-embed is-type-rich is-provider-twitter wp-block-embed-twitter\"><div class=\"wp-block-embed__wrapper\">\nhttps:\/\/twitter.com\/bfreshwa\/status\/1803823968547217903\n<\/div><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:embed -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The driver diagnosed the issue on locked back brakes, saying that their attempts at <a href=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/video\/tesla-cybertruck-steering-wheel-appears-to-lag\/\">steering the heavy vehicle away from the neighbor's home were futile.<\/a><\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Tesla had already recalled 4,000 Cybertrucks in April over faulty accelerator pedals that may dislodge, which may cause the pedal to become trapped in the interior trim above the pedal.\u201d<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The issue increases the risk of a collision as the driver loses the ability to properly use both the accelerator and the brake pedals.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32603298,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Dfreshwa\/X\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000084523252\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/06\/twitter-com-bfreshwa-status-1803869635827114217-84523252.jpg?w=847\" alt=\"The damaged truck in the driver.\" class=\"wp-image-32603298\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">The Cybertruck careened roughly 800 feet, the driver said, leaving a 50-foot trail of skid marks in its wake.\n\n<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>To make matters worse, the driver didn't know how to access the emergency break. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p><a href=\"https:\/\/www.tesla.com\/ownersmanual\/cybertruck\/en_us\/GUID-8EA7EF10-7D27-42AC-A31A-96BCE5BC0A85.html#:~:text=Automatic%20Emergency%20Braking%20is%20always,touchscreen%20displays%20a%20visual%20message.\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">According to Tesla's website<\/a>, emergency braking is an automatic feature for the car accessible on the touch screen rather than as a physical handle.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The tech car company reportedly told the driver that \"depressing the brake may or may not disengage accelerator.\" <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>When it comes to the outrageous cost of fixing the four-hour-old car, they simply said: \"Deal with your insurance company.\"<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32603301,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Dfreshwa\/X\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000084523259\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/06\/twitter-com-bfreshwa-status-1803869635827114217-84523259.jpg?w=768\" alt=\"The damaged car.\" class=\"wp-image-32603301\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">According to the driver, repairs for the truck would cost around $30,000 -- but would take a year for the right parts to arrive.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Tesla did not immediately respond to The Post's request for comment.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The incident is the latest in a string of issues with the futuristic-looking truck.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nyp-membership\/comments \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Elon Musk's company recalled 11,000 of the electric pickups Tuesday to fix issues related to fatuity windshield wipers and trim in the truck bed -- two separate issues.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Last month, the Cybertruck went viral after a video showed an extreme lag on the vehicle\u2019s steer-by-wire system, sparking a new wave of safety to include her dog on a month-long holiday around Italy says it was \"totally worth it.\"\u00a0<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Catherine Sophie didn't want to leave behind her beloved 3-year-old Maltese, named Teddy as she galavanted around Italy for a month \u2014 so she decided to bring him as her travel buddy, no matter the cost. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph wp:nypost-newspress\/multi-titles \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>A North Carolina high school senior was killed just days before her graduation when the camper she was in was crushed by a falling tree.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Kara Bryson, 18, died on Monday morning when winds of 50 to 70 mph uprooted a large tree, which crushed the trailer she was staying in at Penland Point Campground, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.themountaineer.com\/news\/best-friend-recalls-tragedy-that-claimed-the-life-of-tuscola-cheerleader\/article_9cb651dc-1d2f-11ef-b8b4-472ea1916108.html\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">according to the Mountaineer<\/a>.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Bryson was a senior at Tuscola High School, and was set to graduate on Friday, the outlet noted. <\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32267538,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Courtesy of family\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000082925770\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/05\/kara-bryson-high-school-senior-82925770.jpg?w=1024\" alt=\"Kara Bryson, 18, died on Monday.\" class=\"wp-image-32267538\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">Kara Bryson, 18, died on Monday.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>She was visiting the Lake Chatuge area for the weekend with friends, including her closest friend and fellow cheerleader Callie Parker.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>\u201cI put my hands over my head because I wasn\u2019t sure what it was,\u201d Parker recalled of hearing the sounds of a thunderstorm, followed by a large crash.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nypost-editor\/primary-tag {\"module_type\":\"more\",\"primary_tag\":34649,\"primary_section\":103,\"align\":\"center\",\"supportsAlign\":true,\"autoPosition\":true,\"lock\":{\"move\":true,\"remove\":false}} \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>\u201cIt was still pouring, the rain. I was just in complete shock,\u201d she said of the moment she scrambled out of the wrecked trailer and dialed 911.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Bryson was already dead when first responders arrived, <a href=\"https:\/\/www.facebook.com\/ClayCountyNCEMS\/posts\/pfbid033y9fv7d5E4Jy1fD3qZMhzBzeDs75EhKhmY74hPbdbw66Euu8azFKBrejQ26czEt5l\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noreferrer noopener\">according to Clay County Emergency Services<\/a>.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32267505,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Courtesy of family\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000082925754\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/05\/kara-bryson-nursing-fundamentals-program-82925754.jpg?w=1024\" alt=\"Kara Bryson.\" class=\"wp-image-32267505\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">Bryson (right) obtained her CNA license the week before she died.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Parker and Bryson recently got ready for prom night together, and had been looking forward to preparing for graduation side-by-side.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Now, Parker will decorate a chair in her best friend's honor for the Friday night ceremony, the Mountaineer said.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>Bryson was in the Nursing Fundamentals program at Tuscola and earned her Certified Nursing Assistant license the week before her death, the outlet added.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>She planned to attend Haywood Community College for the first two years of her undergraduate degree, and hoped to eventually become a nurse.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image {\"align\":\"center\",\"id\":32267507,\"sizeSlug\":\"large\",\"linkDestination\":\"none\",\"credits\":\"Courtesy of family\",\"chpId\":\"NYPICHPDPICT000082925743\"} -->\n<figure class=\"wp-block-image aligncenter size-large\"><img src=\"https:\/\/nypost.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/sites\/2\/2024\/05\/kara-bryson-got-ready-prom-82925743.jpg?w=768\" alt=\"Bryson and her friend Callie Parker.\" class=\"wp-image-32267507\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">Byrson (right) and her best friend Callie Parker were camping with a friend's family for Memorial Day weekend.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The teen was also an active member of the cheerleading squad \u2013 and was a leader in the group even after she injured her shoulder during her senior season.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>\u201cShe would try to persuade us to still let her stunt. She was driven. She had a tough mindset and mentality to push through,\u201d cheer coach Kari Setser told the Mountaineer.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>\u201cShe didn\u2019t sit there and pout. She would always ask \u2018What can I do to help? What else can I do?\u2019\u201d she added.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:nyp-membership\/comments \/-->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>The cheer team called Bryson\u2019s death a \u201chorrible loss\u201d in an emotional Facebook tribute.<\/p>\n<!-- \/wp:paragraph -->\n\n<!-- wp:image class=\"wp-image-32267504\" \/><figcaption class=\"wp-element-caption\">Bryson was a beloved high school cheerleader.<\/figcaption><\/figure>\n<!-- \/wp:image -->\n\n<!-- wp:paragraph -->\n<p>In readabilityObject.title: RFK Jr. says COVID may have been 'ethnically targeted' to spare Jews
readabilityObject.content:
Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. dished out wild COVID-19 conspiracy theories this week during a press event at an Upper East Side restaurant, claiming the bug was a genetically engineered bioweapon that may have been “ethnically targeted” to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people.

Kennedy floated the idea during a question-and-answer portion of raucous booze and fart-filled dinner at Tony’s Di Napoli on East 63d Street.

“COVID-19. There is an argument that it is ethnically targeted. COVID-19 attacks certain races disproportionately,” Kennedy said. “COVID-19 is targeted to attack Caucasians and black people. The people who are most immune are Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese.”

“We don’t know whether it was deliberately targeted or not but there are papers out there that show the racial or ethnic differential and impact,” Kennedy hedged.

In between bites of linguini and clam sauce, Kennedy, 69, warned of more dire biological weapons in the pipeline with a “50% infection fatality rate” that would make COVID-19 “look like a walk in the park.”

“We do know that the Chinese are spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing ethnic bioweapons and we are developing ethnic bioweapons,” he claimed. “They’re collecting Russian DNA. They’re collecting Chinese DNA so we can target people by race.”

There has been a growing consensus among US intelligence agencies that COVID-19 was man-made and escaped from a lab in Wuhan, China — but there is no evidence it was designed to spare certain religious groups or ethnicities, and Kennedy offered no studies to support his claims.

Kennedy’s remark echoes well-worn anti-Semitic literature blaming Jews for the emergence and spread of coronavirus which began circulating online shortly after the pandemic broke out, according to The Center for the Study of Contemporary European Jewry at the University of Tel Aviv’s 2021 Antisemitism Worldwide Report.

A 2020 Oxford University study found nearly 1 in 5 British people believed Jews created the coronavirus pandemic for financial gain.

“No no no no no,” said Dr. Monica Gandhi Professor of medicine and infectious disease at the University of California, San Francisco, and a longtime critic of pandemic-related school closures. “I don’t see any evidence that there was any design or bioterrorism that anyone tried to design something to knock off certain groups.”

Jewish organizations blasted Kennedy for his remarks.

“This is crazy,” said Morton Klein, President of the right-leaning Zionist Organization of America. “It makes no sense that they would do that. I read everything. I was totally against the vaccine. . . I wanted to convince myself it was correct not to take it. I have never seen anything like this.”

Klein, who said he had been advising Kennedy on Israel issues and called him a “good friend,” said the remark left him “worried.”

The son of former Attorney General Robert Kennedy and nephew of former President Kennedy has in the past palled around with Nation of Islam leader and notorious anti-Semite Louis Farrakhan.

He also met with NOI leadership in Los Angeles in 2020 and told them the COVID vaccine had been “genetically modified to attack black and Latino boys.”

The left-leaning Anti-Defamation League went further saying in a statement saying: “The claim that COVID-19 was a bioweapon created by the Chinese or Jews to attack Caucasians and black people is deeply offensive and feeds into sinophobic and anti-semitic conspiracy theories about COVID-19 that we have seen evolve over the last three years.”

Kennedy’s campaign has drawn in disaffected elements of both the right and left seeking an alternative to mainstream candidates.

Some polls have shown him garnering 20% support among primary voters.

Kennedy called The Post’s “mistaken,” tweeting Saturday that the event had been off the record, but event organizer Doug Dechert told The Post it was on the record.

A second event attendee confirmed  to The Post Dechert told him the same thing. 

“The U.S. and other governments are developing ethnically targeted bioweapons and that a 2021 study of the COVID-19 virus shows that COVID-19 appears to disproportionately affect certain races,” Kennedy tweeted — reiterating his remarks from the dinner. “The furin cleave docking site is most compatible with blacks and Caucasians and least compatible with ethnic Chinese, Finns, and Ashkenazi Jews. In that sense, it serves as a kind of proof of concept for ethnically targeted bioweapons.”

“I do not believe and never implied that the ethnic effect was deliberately engineered,” he added — clarifying his recorded remarks.
readabilityObject.textContent:
Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr. dished out wild COVID-19 conspiracy theories this week during a press event at an Upper East Side restaurant,  claiming the bug was a genetically engineered bioweapon that may have been “ethnically targeted” to spare Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese people.



Kennedy floated the idea during a question-and-answer portion of raucous booze and fart-filled dinner at Tony’s Di Napoli on East 63d Street.



“COVID-19. There is an argument that it is ethnically targeted. COVID-19 attacks certain races disproportionately,” Kennedy said. “COVID-19 is targeted to attack Caucasians and black people. The people who are most immune are Ashkenazi Jews and Chinese.”



“We don’t know whether it was deliberately targeted or not but there are papers out there that show the racial or ethnic differential and impact,” Kennedy hedged.



In between bites of linguini and clam sauce, Kennedy, 69, warned of more dire biological weapons in the pipeline with a “50% infection fatality rate” that would make COVID-19 “look like a walk in the park.”  



“We do know that the Chinese are spending hundreds of millions of dollars developing ethnic bioweapons and we are developing ethnic bioweapons,” he claimed.  “They’re collecting Russian DNA. They’re collecting Chinese DNA so we can target people by race.”





There has been a growing consensus among US intelligence agencies that COVID-19 was man-made and escaped from a lab in Wuhan, China — but there is no evidence it was designed to spare certain religious groups or ethnicities, and Kennedy offered no studies to support his claims. 



Kennedy’s remark echoes well-worn anti-Semitic literature blaming Jews for the emergence and spread of coronavirus which began circulating online shortly after the pandemic broke out, according to The Center for the Study of Contemporary European Jewry at the University of Tel Aviv’s 2021 Antisemitism Worldwide Report. 



A 2020 Oxford University study found nearly 1 in 5 British people believed Jews created the coronavirus pandemic for financial gain.  



“No no no no no,” said Dr. Monica Gandhi Professor of medicine and infectious disease at the University of California, San Francisco, and a longtime critic of pandemic-related school closures. “I don’t see any evidence that there was any design or bioterrorism that anyone tried to design something to knock off certain groups.” 



Jewish organizations blasted Kennedy for his remarks. 




Kennedy is running as a Democratic candidate for president in a long-shot race against President Biden. John Lamparski/Getty Images



“This is crazy,” said Morton Klein, President of the right-leaning Zionist Organization of America. “It makes no sense that they would do that. I read everything. I was totally against the vaccine. . . I wanted to convince myself it was correct not to take it. I have never seen anything like this.”



Klein, who said he had been advising Kennedy on Israel issues and called him a “good friend,” said the remark left him “worried.” 



The son of former Attorney General Robert Kennedy and nephew of former President Kennedy has in the past palled around with Nation of Islam leader and notorious anti-Semite Louis Farrakhan. 



He also met with NOI leadership in Los Angeles in 2020 and told them the COVID vaccine had been “genetically modified to attack black and Latino boys.”




While there has been speculation that Covid-19 was manmade and escaped from a lab, there is no evidence it was designed to spare certain religious groups or ethnicities. Getty Images



The left-leaning Anti-Defamation League went further saying in a statement saying: “The claim that COVID-19 was a bioweapon created by the Chinese or Jews to attack Caucasians and black people is deeply offensive and feeds into sinophobic and anti-semitic conspiracy theories about COVID-19 that we have seen evolve over the last three years.”



Kennedy’s campaign has drawn in disaffected elements of both the right and left seeking an alternative to mainstream candidates. 



Some polls have shown him garnering 20% support among primary voters. 



Kennedy called The Post’s “mistaken,” tweeting Saturday that the event had been off the record, but event organizer Doug Dechert told The Post it was on the record.







A second event attendee confirmed  to The Post Dechert told him the same thing. 



“The U.S. and other governments are developing ethnically targeted bioweapons and that a 2021 study of the COVID-19 virus shows that COVID-19 appears to disproportionately affect certain races,” Kennedy tweeted — reiterating his remarks from the dinner. “The furin cleave docking site is most compatible with blacks and Caucasians and least compatible with ethnic Chinese, Finns, and Ashkenazi Jews. In that sense, it serves as a kind of proof of concept for ethnically targeted bioweapons.”



“I do not believe and never implied that the ethnic effect was deliberately engineered,” he added — clarifying his recorded remarks.
